message:
Hey geeks, I have a question..

If I've developed some project to someone and he asked me for the source code of this project, do I have the right to say no?

And what about this scenario in enterprise-to-enterprise situation?

data.message:
For me my personal opinion is i wrote this code for him so it doesn't matter if i will give him the code or not. 
but most of developers take extra money for the source code.
that depends on you yahia , if you want to accept so you will tell him that salary will get higher to get source code
Source code means more money unless a prior agreement.
It all depends on the agreement, having a license to use a product doesn't mean you have the right to the code.

Agree that it is based on Agreement, but I don't think hiding the source is an option any more, I think the agreement should be made immediately to include the source code. The days of proprietary software are coming to an end.

Muhammad Even distributing the source code doesn't equal the right to produce and resell or claiming ownership of it, all these are separate rights, you can't claim the ownership of Linux source code, and you can't sell it either without adhering to the license.
So bottom line is the License is everything, if you want to grant rights to someone, it has to be explicit in the license, even if the source code is open, doesn't imply other rights.

Mohamed Elsherif true, but Free Software: you can modify, refactor, resell, rebrand the sourcecode as long as the output is free software. I can own the Linux source code and so can you in the sense that we can take it, modify it, brand it, sell it, we just can't make it proprietary, that's the whole idea.  With enough Free Software around, there will be no  reason to close the source code any more

Muhammad again, it all depends on the original license, Free software couldn't have been free without having licenses like GPL, LGPL, MIT, BDS, Apache, ... etc, the original author of the software, decided to grant certain rights to the end user.
Yahia Allam depends on the contract , if this is not mentioned its ur right to say, by default you do not have to deliver source code.
